title: Question 5
content: After $1960$, the economy growth in Australia has grown in an exponential fashion. Australian GDP per capita, $G(t)$, in United States dollars (USD) is modelled by the function $$ G(t) = 1806 \times (1.037)^t, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the number of years since $1960$, and $t \geq 0$. - Write down, in USD, Australian GDP per capita in $1960$. [1] - Find Australian GDP per capita in $1961$. [1] - Find the year for which Australian GDP per capita reaches $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ USD. Give your answer correct to the nearest year. [4]
markScheme:
- $\answer{1806 \text{ USD}}$
- Evaluating $G(t)$ for $t = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} G(1) &= 1806 \times (1.037) \\[6pt]
  &= 1872.822 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1870 \text{ USD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $G(t) = 100\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} 1806 \times (1.037)^t &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 110 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence Australian GDP per capita reaches $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ USD
in  $\answer{2070}$

title: Question 8
content: The average daily hours of sunlight, $S$, during a 12-month period in a particular town is given by the function $$ S(t)=a\cos(bt-180)+d, $$ where time, $t$, is measured in months, $a$ and $d$ are constants, and $b$ is measured in degrees. The graph of $S$ versus $t$ is shown in the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8a6e0bdd-88f9-4d71-8c34-6feeedb1d7e0/images/4284ab68-f212-4ca3-8085-e16d1ab13767/aff649079ad71d825a6dc0770f6728fb76b7cce5.svg) - Find the value of - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Write down the values of $t$ when the average daily sunlight is $10$ hours. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}-S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16-4) \\[6pt]
    % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=6}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}+S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16+4) \\[6pt]
    %   &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(20) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=10}
    \end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $S$ is 12 months. Hence, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &=\dfrac{\ang{360}}{\text{period}} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
  & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=\ang{30}}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- The graph of $S$ versus $t$ shows that $S(3) =10$ and $S(9) =10$.
Hence, the average daily sunlight hours is 10 for
$\answer{t=3\hspace{0.525em}\text{and}\hspace{0.525em} t=9.}$

title: Question 10
content: A population of $50$ hamsters was introduced to a new town. One month later, the number of hamsters was $62$. The number of hamsters, $P$, can be modelled by the function $$ P(t) = 50\times b^t,\hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the time, in months, since the hamsters were introduced to the town. - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Calculate the number of hamsters in the town after $6$ months. [2] A wildlife specialist estimates that the town has enough drink and food to support a maximum population of $2000$ hamsters. - Calculate the number of months it takes for the hamster population to reach this maximum. [2]
markScheme:
- Solving the equation $P(1) = 62$ for $b$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times b^1 &= 62 \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{62}{50} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.4em}\answer{b = 1.24}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 6$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} P(6) &= 50\times(1.24)^6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 182}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 2000$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times(1.24)^t &= 2000 \hspace{3.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.6em} \answer{t \approx 17.1 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 13
content: The orbital velocity, $v$, of a spacecraft in km/s is given by $$ v = -0.0098t + c \ln R, $$ where $t$ is the firing time in seconds, $c$ is the exhaust velocity in km/s and $R$ is the mass ratio. If $R=30$, find - The orbital velocity, $v$, after a firing time of 150 seconds and an exhaust velocity of 3 km/s. [2] - The exhaust velocity, $c$, of the spacecraft traveling at an orbital velocity of $9.5 \text{ km/s}$ after a firing time of 150 seconds. [3]
markScheme:
- Substituting in $t=150$, $c=3$ and $R=30$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  v &= -0.0098(150) + (3) \ln (30)\hspace{0.5cm}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 8.73 \text{ km/s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting in $v=9.5$, $t=150$ and $R=30$, we can solve for $c$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9.5 &= -0.0098(150) + c \ln (30)\hspace{0.5cm}\\[8pt]
  c \ln (30) &= 9.5 + 0.0098(150)\\[8pt]
  c &= \dfrac{9.5+0.0098(150)}{\ln (30)}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 3.23 \text{ km/s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 21

Its height, $H$ , in metres, above the ground is modelled by the function $$ H(t) = 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 80, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in seconds, since the turbine was accelerated to its max speed. - Write down the minimum height of the blade's tip above the ground.   $$

  \hspace{1.5em} H(8) &= 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 8) + 80 \\[6pt]
  &= 52\sin \ang{480} + 80 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 125\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/345633bb-e844-436b-bd39-eff8642672ef/images/5f3d01f7-4c01-4f77-b034-46af9d83cc7a/279de316931380f9a5da6848695c261465d527a8.svg)

title: Question 29
content: The subscription fee for an online project management software by AB-Tech is $\$ 40$ per month. If the customer buys for a whole year in advance, a discount of $\$130$ is applied. This can be modelled by the following function, $P(n)$, which gives the total cost when paying annually for the subscription. $$ P(n) = 40n - 130,\quad n\geq 12 $$ where $n$ is the number months. - Find the total cost of buying a subscription for $2$ years. [2] - Find $P^{-1}(1790)$. [2] The subscription price for a different online project management tool by YZ-tech is $\$35$ per month, however customers can only purchase annually in advance, and there are no discounts. The total subscription cost of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's software when $n>k$ . - Find the minimum value of $k$. [3]
markScheme:
- Substituting $n=24$ into the $P(n)$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(n) &=40n-130\\[6pt]
  P(24) &= 40(24)-130 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{=\$ 830}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(n)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $n$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 40n-130 \\[6pt]
  n&=40y-130\\[6pt]
  40y&=n+130\\[6pt]
  y&=\dfrac{n+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  P^{-1}(n) &= \dfrac{n+130}{40}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We can now find
$P^{-1}(1790)$ as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P^{-1}(1790)&=\dfrac{1790+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-3.5em}\answer{P^{-1}(1790)=48 \text{ months}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For AB-tech's software we we were given the pricing function

  $$
  P(n)=40n-130
  
  $$

  For YZ-tech, we can define the function, $S(n)$, to
represent the subscription price for their software

  $$
  S(n)=35n
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2b908e8c-786e-4fec-844c-19b9653ea308/images/7386b1f2-6825-49b7-88df-da2a1e5501e7/7402d7e1fc9d51e4e9f6b0f5ea74f75143d1438e.svg)


  From the graph, $S(n) < P(n)$ for $n>26$.
  The price of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's when $n>26$.

title: Question 59
content: A cannon-ball is fired from the top of a tower. title: Question 65
content: The graph shows the curve of a quadratic function of the form $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + 90$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6886819b-3fbd-43d3-95f6-61cf97d171c1/images/abf35098-dbcc-4ba6-a3af-f17c013fd694/e02d6931ce58420fa7c9cbe422473aefce55e151.svg) - Write down the equation for the axis of symmetry of the curve. markScheme:
- The axis of symmetry intersects the $x$-axis midway between the
$x$-intercepts.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.15em} x &= \dfrac{-5+9}{2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.4em} \answer{x = 2}
  $$

- Using the coordinates of A, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-5) &= 0 \\[6pt]

title: Question 68
content: A population of goldfish decreases exponentially. The size of the population, $P$, after $t$ days is modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} P(t) = 8000\times2^{-t} + 100, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0. \\ \end{aligned} $$ - Write down the exact size of the initial population. [2] - Calculate the time it will take for the size of the population to decrease to $120$.[2] The population will stabilize when it reaches a size of $n$. - Write down the value of $n$. [1]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.7em} P(0) &= 8000\times2^0 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &= 8000 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8100}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.3em} P(5) &= 8000\times2^{-5} + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 350}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 120$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  8000\times2^{-t} + 100 &= 120 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{t = 8.64 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.9em} \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} P(t) &= \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} \big[8000\times2^{-t} + 100\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 0+100 \hspace{2em} [\text{since $2^{-t} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$}] \\[10pt]
  &= 100 \text{ days}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the value of $n$ is
$\answer{100}$

title: Question 69
content: The decibel scale measures how loud a sound is to the human ear. The decibel rating, $\mathrm{dB}$, of a sound can be modelled as a function of its sound intensity, $I$, as shown by the equation $$ \begin{align*} \mathrm{dB} = 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120 \end{align*} $$ Where $I$ is measured in Watts per square metre $(\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2)$ and $I>0$. The pain threshold for the average human ear is $130\,\mathrm{dB}$. - Show that the pain threshold is reached at exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. [1] Amelia has a diesel generator that has a sound intensity of $1 \times 10^{-3.5}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. - Determine the decibel rating of Amelia's generator. [2] Amelia is considering replacing her old diesel generator and has discovered a quieter petrol generator that has a decibel rating of $50\,\mathrm{dB}$. - Determine the sound intensity of the petrol generator. Give your answer in the form $a \times 10^k$ where $1 \leq a < 10$ and $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.[2] - Find how many times greater the sound intensity of the diesel generator is compared to the petrol generator.[2]
markScheme:
- Substituting $I=10$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,10 + 120 = 130
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The pain threshold of $130\,\mathrm{dB}$ is reached at a sound intensity of exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.
- Substituting $I=1 \times 10^{-3.5}$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{dB} &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,\left(1 \times 10^{-3.5}\right) + 120 \\[8pt]
  &= 85
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{Amelia's generator has a rating of }85\,\mathrm{dB}.}$
- Substituting $\mathrm{dB}=50$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And we know that $0<I<10^{-3.5}$. Using the numeric solver on the G.D.C. we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{nSolve}\big(50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120\,,I\,\big)\,|\,0<I<10^{-3.5} \\[8pt]
  I &= 0.0000001
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{The sound intensity of the petrol generator is }1 \times 10^{-7}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2.}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \dfrac{1 \times 10^{-3.5}}{1 \times 10^{-7}} \approx 3162
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The sound intensity of the diesel generator is approximately 3160 times greater than the sound intensity of the petrol generator.

title: Question 72
content: A set of BMX jumping ramps have been constructed at a local cycle park, as shown in the following diagram. It is designed for riders to take off from the first ramp, represented by $f(x)$, and land on the second ramp, represented by $g(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e6fba44-ae40-4292-a287-5720870a3e3e/images/72e41c7b-2eb3-46ea-a3bd-57ec52baf40b/1197a.JPG) $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ The first ramp starts at the origin and ends at point $A$, and has equation $f(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^2 \text{ for } 0\leq x \leq 3$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ The second ramp starts at point $C$ and ends at point $E$, and has equation $g(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^2-8x+48 \text{ for } 9\leq x \leq 12$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ $p(x)$ represents the path a rider would take in the air between the ramps between point $A$ and point $C$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ $q(x)$ represents a safety net that hangs between point $A$ and point $C$, and has equation $q(x)=\dfrac{1}{9} x^2-\dfrac{4}{3} x+6 \text{ for } 3\leq x \leq 9$. $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ Point $A$ has coordinates (3,3) and point $C$ has coordinates (9,3). It is given that all units and measurements are in metres. The path of a rider at point $A$ is the tangent to $f(x)$ at that point. - - Determine the gradient of $f(x)$ at point $A$. - Hence, determine the equation of the path of a rider at point $A$. Give your answer in the form $y=mx+c$.[4] The line $BC$ represents a support beam and is a normal to $g(x)$ at point $C$. - - Determine the gradient of $g(x)$ at point $C$. - Hence, determine the equation of the line representing the support beam $BC$.[6] $p(x)$ is a parabola with a maximum at (6,6). - Determine the equation of $p(x)$.[2] A safety regulation at the cycle park is that a BMX rider using the jumping ramps should never be more than 5 metres above the safety net while in the air. - Determine whether the model predicts that this safety regulation will be upheld. [4]

title: Question 73
content: A loaf pan is made in the shape of a cylinder. The pan has a diameter of $24$ cm and a height of $5$ cm. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aaafe79-56c4-4a37-b409-43676a3d5eed/images/855b65c5-7644-44f9-a953-a91912965eb3/a347288bee589088e6dce052611dad40b73c72e7.svg) - Calculate the volume of this pan. [3] Gloria prepares enough bread dough to exactly fill the pan. The dough was in the shape of a sphere. - Find the radius of the sphere in cm, correct to one decimal place. [4] The bread was cooked in a hot oven. Once taken out of the oven, the bread was left in the kitchen. The temperature, $T$, of the bread, in degrees Celsius, $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, can be modelled by the function $$ T(t) = a\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0, $$ where $a$ is a constant and $t$ is the time, in minutes, since the bread was taken out of the oven. When the bread was taken out of the oven its temperature was $205$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Find the value of $a$. [2] - Find the temperature that the bread will be $10$ minutes after it is taken out of the oven. [2] The bread can be eaten once its temperature drops to $35$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Calculate, to the nearest minute, the time since the bread was taken out of the oven until it can be eaten. [3] - In the context of this model, state what the value of $21$ represents. [1]
markScheme:
- Using the volume of a cylinder formula with $r = 12$ and $h = 5$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.05em} V_{\text{pan}} &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  &= \pi(12)^2(5) \\[6pt]
  &= 720\pi \qref{(1)}  \\[6pt]
  &=2261.9...\\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 2260 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the volume of a sphere formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} V_{\text{dough}} &= V_{\text{pan}} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3 &= 720\pi \hspace{3em} [\text{from  $(1)$}] \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $r$, we obtain

  $$
  \hspace{12.9em} \answer{r \approx 8.1 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(0) = 205$ for $a$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\times(1.51)^0 + 21 &= 205 \hspace{5.65em} \\[6pt]
  a + 21 &= 205 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{a = 184}
  $$

- Evaluating $T(t)$ for $t=10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} T(10) &= 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{10}{3}} + 21 \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 67.6 \text{\hspace{0.15em}\textdegree{C}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(t) = 35$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21 &= 35 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 18.8 \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.8em} \answer{t \approx 19 \text{ minutes}}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{\(21\) is the room  temperature of the kitchen}}$

title: Question 75
content: The half-life, $T$, in years, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned} $$ where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per year of the isotope. - The decay rate of Hydrogen-$3$ is $5.5$ % per year. Find its half-life.[2] The half-life of Uranium-$232$ (U-$232$) is $68.9$ years. A sample containing $250$ grams of U-$232$ is obtained and stored as a side product of a nuclear fuel cycle. - Find the decay rate per year of U-$232$. [2] - Find the amount of U-$232$ left in the sample after: - $68.9$ years; - $100$ years. [3]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 5.5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(5.5) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{5.5}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 12.3 \text{ years}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 68.9$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 68.9 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.3em} \answer{k = 1.00\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{125 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 250$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 1.00/100) = 0.99$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=101$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    u_{101} &= u_1r^{101-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 250\hspace{0.05em}(0.99)^{101-1} \hspace{0.2em} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 91.5 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 77
content: The half-life, $T$, in days, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned} $$ where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per day of the isotope. - The decay rate of Gold-$196$ is $6.2$ % per day. Find its half-life.[2] The half-life of Phosphorus-$32$ (P-$32$) is $14.3$ days. A sample containing $120$ grams of P-$32$ is produced and stored in a biochemistry laboratory. - Find the decay rate per day of P-$32$. [2] - Find the amount of P-$32$ left in the sample after: - $14.3$ days; - $50$ days. [3]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 6.2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(6.2) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{6.2}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 10.8 \text{ days}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 14.3$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 14.3 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.25em} \answer{k = 4.73\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{60 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 120$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 4.73/100) = 0.9527$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=51$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.8em} u_{51} &= u_1r^{51-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 120\hspace{0.05em}(0.9527)^{51-1} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 10.6 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 78
content: The Burj Khalifa, located in Dubai, is the tallest building in the world. It has a height of $830 \text{ m}$ and has a square base that covers a floor area of $556 \text{ m} \times 556 \text{ m}$. A tourism shop located near the building sells souvenirs of the tower, which sit inside glass pyramids, as illustrated by the diagram below. The souvenir tower is an accurate scale replica of the actual tower. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/490aa73b-d0b9-484e-9cf9-6362beb9193f/75dbfe1df45464ae26235a84b47e84fedd3f43ea.svg) The scaled model of Burj Khalifa has a base area of $20 \text{ cm} \times 20 \text{ cm}$. The height and base area dimensions of the glass pyramid are 10% larger than the model. - - Find the height of the souvenir tower, in cm, correct to the nearest mm. - Find the volume of the glass pyramid, rounding your answer correct to the nearest cubic centimetre. [5] The shop owner aims to maximise profits from selling the souvenirs. The more the owner orders from the manufacturer, the cheaper the souvenirs are to buy. However, if too many are ordered, profits may decrease due to surplus stock unsold. The number of souvenirs ordered from previous years and the resulting profits are shown in the following table. QuantityProfit($)$5000$$35\,000$$10\,000$$95\,500$$13\,000$$116\,500$ The shop owner decides to fit a cubic model of the form $$ P(x) = ax^3+bx^2+cx+d $$ to model the profit, $P$, for $x$ thousand souvenirs ordered. - Explain why $d=0$.[1] - Construct three linear equations to solve for $a$, $b$ and $c$, and hence write down the completed function $P(x)$. [5] - Find $P'(x)$.[2] - Find, to the nearest hundred souvenirs, the optimal number of souvenirs the owner should buy to maximise profit, and the resulting profit from this number. [4]
markScheme:
- 
  - The height $(h_m)$ of the model can be calculated by

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    h_m&= \text{height of Burj Khalifa} \times \text{scale factor}\\[6pt]
    &= 83000 \times \dfrac{20}{55600}\hspace{4.1em} [\text{all values in cm}] \\[6pt]
    &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 29.9 \text{ cm} }\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Let $x$ be the side length of the base and $h$ be the height of
the glass pyramid. Since the dimensions of glass pyramid are
$10\%$ larger than the model, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x&= 20+20(0.1)\hspace{2cm} \\[6pt]
    &= 22 \text{ cm}\\[6pt]
    h&= 29.9+29.9(0.1)\\[6pt]
    &\approx 32.9 \text{ cm}\end{aligned}
    $$


  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/19611668-b3b5-4172-ace2-b6f0010e0b75/c16aa6b415e3ff65a129bf040b3ec43c108d55ec.svg)


  The volume $(V)$ of the glass pyramid can therefore be calculated by

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V&= \dfrac{1}{3}\times x^2 \times h \\[6pt]
  &=\dfrac{1}{3}\times (22)^2 \times(32.9)\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 5308 \text{ cm}^3 }\end{aligned}
  $$

- If zero souvenirs are ordered (i.e. $x=0$), there won't be any
souvenirs to sell. Hence, the profit, $P$, will also be zero.

  $$
  \answer{P(0)=0, \,\text{ hence } \, d=0 }
  $$

- Since $x$ is in thousands, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(5)&=5^3a+5^2b+5c=35\, 000\qref{(1)}\\[6pt]
  P(10) &= 10^3a+10^2b+10c = 95\, 500\qref{(2)}\\[6pt]
  P(13) &= 13^3a+13^2b+13c = 116\, 500 \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using
G.D.C. to solve the equations $(1)$, $(2)$ and $(3)$, we get

  $$
  a=-\dfrac{2295}{26},\, b=\dfrac{47685}{26}, \text{ and } c=\dfrac{475}{13}
  $$

  Hence

  $$
  \hspace{0.3em}\answer{P(x) =-\dfrac{2295}{26}x^3+\dfrac{47685}{26}x^2+\dfrac{475}{13}x}
  $$

- Differentiating $P(x)$ with respect to $x$, we get

  $$
  \hspace{0.3em}\answer{P'(x) =-\dfrac{6885}{26}x^2+\dfrac{47685}{13}x+\dfrac{475}{13}}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $P(x)$, the maximum profit occurs at point
A.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/01769894-ccf2-4567-9e25-00dfe1fa2901/5541c9fa3d0d1b43403859281edadfc0d340eef4.svg)


  Using G.D.C. to find the coordinates of A, we get

  $$
  x=13.9, \text{ and } P(x)\approx 118\,000
  $$

  Hence,
  The maximum profit will occur when the owner buys
$\hspace{0.4em}\answer{13\,900}\hspace{0.4em}$ souvenirs.
The resulting profit will be approximately
$\hspace{0.35em}\answer{118\,000.}$

title: Question 85
content: A particular species of microbes is studied in the laboratory. Microbes are grown under controlled conditions in pure culture. The number of microbes, $N$, present in the culture $t$ hours after the start of the experiment are recorded. The results are shown in the table below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/e0c72216-8582-4a43-b865-6568739b5e03/05f74794f9493b7052849a256cb95a218dff9b51.svg) - Complete the third row of the table above. [2] - Draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, scaling the axes if needed. [3] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] A scientist in the laboratory claims that the number of microbes, $N$, grown in the laboratory during the experiment can be modelled by an exponential function of the form $N(t) = a\times b^t$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants. - Explain why the scientist is correct. [4] - Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4]
markScheme:
- Calculating the values of $\log N$, we get

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/04df3b88-45a9-4949-aa9e-88b0f0bf335c/6cf620ba27d00fb0d7be6bd8c31f6e9e22c0c9ce.svg)



- If we draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/18131649-4993-445a-99d1-5cf1380f097e/73d2d06aa23839e33065bdf471930d83ad8030b6.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- Using the properties of exponents, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \log N(t) &= mt + c \hspace{3em} [\text{by parts (b) and (c)}] \\[8pt]
  10^{mt+c} &= N(t) \hspace{3em} [\text{by definition of log}] \\[8pt]
  (10^{mt})(10^c) &= N(t) \\[8pt]
  N(t) &= (10^c)(10^{m})^t\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain
$N(t) = a\times b^t$ for $a = 10^c$ and $b = 10^m$.
- The equation of the regression line of $\log N$ on $t$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11em} \log N(t) &= 0.14521t + 1.69035 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} a &= 10^{1.69035} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 49.0}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.3em} b &= 10^{0.14521} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1.40}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 86
content: A right cylinder has height $h$ mm and diameter $x$ mm. The volume of this cylinder is equal to $45$ mm$^3$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/efc9fbc4-0075-415f-b8c9-1a1def8352df/9aebb1d3e12c9fb1c552ed279ae0c28d1ca125c3.svg) The total surface area, $A$, of the cylinder can be expressed as $A = \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{k}{x}$. - Find the value of $k$. [4] - Find the value of $x$ that makes the total surface area a minimum. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the volume of a right cylinder formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  45 &= \pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2\hspace{-0.2em}h \\[3pt]
  45 &= \dfrac{\pi x^2h}{4} \\[6pt]
  h &= \dfrac{180}{\pi x^2} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total surface area is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= [\text{top \& bottom area}] + [\text{curved surface area}] \\[16pt]
  &=  2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh \\[9pt]
  &= 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2 + 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{180}{\pi x^2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{180}{x}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{k = 180}$
- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$, for $x > 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/70443638-b03e-4b02-9371-621e475b9a63/10ad2caa42e46f8e9db41f9ae6642694c0b81ac1.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{x \approx 3.86 \text{  mm}}$
makes the total surface area a minimum.

title: Question 87
content: Peter wants to reach a rock, located $5$ km away from his current position, using the strategy outlined below. Every hour Peter approaches the rock by a fixed percent of the remaining distance to the rock. The distance, $D$, in kilometres, Peter has travelled from his original position, can be modelled by the exponential function $$ \begin{aligned} D(t) = a + b\big(k^{-t}\big), \hspace{0.5em} t\geq 0, \end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the time, in hours, since Peter started moving. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/f49c99b3-6084-4cce-b203-48eef7cf3293/819ba2cfeb3383629fe25649fde3301bcf8c76d4.svg) - Explain why $a= 5$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] After one hour, the distance from Peter to the rock is $3.75$ km. - Find the value of $k$. [2] - Find the distance between Peter and the rock after $4$ hours. [2] Peter can be heard when shouting from $200$ metres away. - Calculate the time it takes until someone standing on the rock can hear Peter shouting. Round your answer correct to the nearest hour. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/749982c8-e46c-4506-bf93-4534155f5e67/284ba0b0f6db44c91e038d4ec5486789b5846da8.svg)


  On the other hand, we know Peter will not travel more than
$5$ km.
  Hence we must have $a = 5$.
- Solving the equation $D(0) = 0$ for $t$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 + b\big(k^{0}\big) &= 0 \hspace{1.6em} \\[6pt]
  5 + b &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.8em} \answer{b = -5}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(1) = 5 - 3.75 = 1.25$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 - 5\big(k^{-1}\big) &= 1.25 \hspace{2.35em} \\[10pt]
  5 - \dfrac{5}{k} &= \dfrac{5}{4} \\[6pt]
  1 - \dfrac{1}{k} &= \dfrac{1}{4} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{k = \dfrac{4}{3}}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} D(4) &= 5 - 5\hspace{-0.15em}\left(\dfrac{4}{3}\right)^{-4} \\[6pt]
  &\approx 3.42\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the distance between Peter and
the rock after $4$ hours is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5  - D(4) &= 5 - 3.42 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1.58 \text{ km}} \hspace{1.4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(t) = 5 - 0.2 = 4.80$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} 5 - 5\big(k^{-t}\big) &= 4.80 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 11.2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it takes
$\answer{11 \text{ hours}}$
until someone on the rock can hear Peter shouting.

title: Question 2
content: In this question give all answers correct to two decimal places. Mia deposits $4000$ Australian dollars (AUD) into a bank account. The bank pays a nominal annual interest rate of $6$ %, compounded semi-annually. - Find the amount of interest that Mia will earn over the next $2.5$ years. [3] Ella also deposits AUD into a bank account. Her bank pays a nominal annual $\text{interest}$ rate of $4$ %, compounded monthly. In $2.5$ years, the total amount in Ella's account will be $4000$ AUD. - Find the amount that Ella deposits in the bank account. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe9fa58e-345a-4e8b-947c-bd0926c22efc/images/89cb9c5a-552f-42ac-ae24-1de2d90c0b31/dc425b29b9e196ccc51470e8966f83917d4179b9.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 4000\bigg(1+\dfrac{6}{100\times2}\bigg)^{2\times2.5} \\[12pt]
  &\approx 4637.10 \text{ AUD}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the amount of interest earned is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} - \text{PV} &\approx 4637.10 - 4000 \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 637.10 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe9fa58e-345a-4e8b-947c-bd0926c22efc/images/5cef2eea-f085-41af-9844-b363be5b4d34/bc195cd8b953f93121c2542be7b715a98cf4c62e.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

He considers an high-growth, higher-risk option, which pays an annual interest of $r\%$, compounding half-yearly. - Determine the value of $r$ required in this option, rounding your answer to two decimal places. [3]
markScheme:
- The compound interest formula is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  FV &= PV\left(1+\dfrac{r}{100k}\right)^{kn} \end{aligned}
  $$

  We
have $FV=2\times 5000 = 10000,\, PV=5000,\, r=4.2,$ and $k=4$.
Substituting these values into the formula, we get

  &\hspace{-0.4em}\answer{\text{n}= 17} \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}

- We have $FV=10000, \,PV=5000,\, k=2,$ and $n=5$.

  $$

content: The coordinates of point K are $(-2,-3)$ and the coordinates of point N are $(8,6)$. M is the midpoint of [KN]. - Find the coordinates of M. [2] $L_1$ is the line which passes through K and N. - Find the gradient of $L_1$. [2] A new line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - - Write down the gradient of $L_2$. - Write down the equation of $L_2$ in the form $y = mx + c$. [3]
markScheme:
- Using the coordinates of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-2 + 8} 2, \dfrac {-3 + 6} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(3, \dfrac 3 2\right)}   \rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the gradient formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &=  \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {6 - (-3)}{8 - (-2)}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \dfrac {9} {10}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    m_{L_2} & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
    &\answer{  = -\dfrac {10}{9}}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - From (c) (i) we have $y = -\dfrac {10}{9} \,x + c$. To find $c$
we substitute the coordinates of M into the equation (since
$L_2$ passes through M).

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac 3 2  & = -\dfrac {10} {9} \left(3 \right) + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
    \dfrac 3 2  & = -\dfrac {10}{3} + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c & = \dfrac 3 2 + \dfrac {10} {3}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c & = \dfrac {29}{6}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of $L_2$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &\answer{ y = -\dfrac {10} {9}\, x + \dfrac {29}{6}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 10
content: The coordinates of point A are $(-1,-7)$ and the coordinates of point $B$ are $(5,2)$. $L_1$ is the line which passes through A and B. - Find the equation of $L_1$. [3] Point M is the midpoint of [AB]. The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - Find the equation of $L_2$. [3]
markScheme:
- First, let's find the gradient of $L_1$. Using the gradient formula,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {2 - (-7)}{5 - (-1)} \rule[-3.7mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  &  = \dfrac{9}{6} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  & = \dfrac 3 2 \rule[0mm]{0pt}{4.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far the
equation of $L_1$ is $y = \dfrac 3 2 \, x + c$. To find $c$ we can
substitute in the coordinates of B into the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2   & = \dfrac 3 2 \,(5) + c\\[6pt]
  c   & = -\dfrac {11} 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L_1$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y    = \dfrac 3 2 \,x - \dfrac {11} 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\
  & = -\dfrac 2 3 \end{aligned}
  $$

  So far we have
$y = -\dfrac 2 3\, x + c$.
  Let's find coordinates of M. Using the coordinates of a midpoint
formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-1 + 5} 2, \dfrac {-7 + 2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(2, -\dfrac 5 2\right)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}  \end{aligned}
  $$

  To find $c$ we can substitute M into the equation (since $L_2$
passes through M).

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -\dfrac 5 2 & = -\dfrac 2 3  (2) + c\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  c   & = -\dfrac 5 2 + \dfrac 4 3\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  c   & = -\dfrac 7 6\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
equation of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y = -\dfrac 2 3  x - \dfrac 7 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 11
content: The coordinates of point A are $(6,-3)$ and the coordinates of point B are $(-2,-1)$. $L_1$ is the line which passes through A and B. - Find the equation of $L_1$. [3] Point M is the midpoint of [AB]. The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - Find the equation of $L_2$. [3]
markScheme:
- First, let's find the gradient of $L_1$. Using the gradient formula,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {-1 - (-3)}{-2 - 6} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &  = \dfrac{2}{-8} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  & = -\dfrac 1 4 \rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far the
equation of $L_1$ is $y = -\dfrac 1 4 \, x + c$. To find $c$ we can
substitute coordinates of B into the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -1  & = -\dfrac 1 4 (-2) + c\\[6pt]
  c   & = -\dfrac 3 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L_1$
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y    = -\dfrac 1 4 \,x - \dfrac 3 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
  & = 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far we have $y = 4 x + c$.
  Let's find the coordinates of the midpoint, M. Using the coordinates
of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {6 - 2} 2, \dfrac {-3 - 1} 2\right)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(2, -2\right)}   \rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}

through M).

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2  & = 4  (2) + c\rule[-1.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  c   & = -2 - 8\rule[-1.5mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
  c   & = -10\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of
$L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y = 4 x - 10}\end{aligned}
  $$

markScheme:

  a_2-a_1 &\neq& a_3-a_2 &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& c_2-c_1 &=& c_3-c_2 \\[12pt]
  5-1 &\neq& 10-5 &&& 3-1.5 &=& 4.5-3 \\[12pt]
  4 &\neq& 5 &&& 1.5 &=& 1.5 \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  b_2-b_1 &\neq& b_3-b_2 &&& d_2-d_1 &\neq& d_3-d_2 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{2}{3}-\dfrac{1}{2} &\neq& \dfrac{3}{4}-\dfrac{2}{3} &&& 1-2 &\neq& \dfrac{1}{2}-1 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{6} &\neq& \dfrac{1}{12} &&& -1 &\neq& -\dfrac{1}{2}
  \end{array} \vspace{0.75em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{c_n}$
is arithmetic and
$\answer{d = 1.5}$
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  \dfrac{a_2}{a_1} &\neq& \dfrac{a_3}{a_2} &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& \dfrac{c_2}{c_1} &\neq& \dfrac{c_3}{c_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{5}{1} &\neq& \dfrac{10}{5} &&& \dfrac{3}{1.5} &\neq& \dfrac{4.5}{3} \\[12pt]
  5 &\neq& 2 &&& 2 &\neq& 1.5 \\[12pt] \hline

  \dfrac{b_2}{b_1} &\neq& \dfrac{b_3}{b_2} &&& \dfrac{d_2}{d_1} &=& \dfrac{d_3}{d_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{2/3}{1/2} &\neq& \dfrac{3/4}{2/3} &&& \dfrac{1}{2} &=& \dfrac{1/2}{1} \\[12pt]

  Hence
$\answer{d_n}$
is geometric and
$\answer{r = \dfrac{1}{2}}$

  $$

  d_8 &= d_1r^{8-1} \\[8pt]

  $$

  \hspace{0.75em} u_6 &= u_1 + (6-1)d \\[6pt]
  42 &= u_1 + 5d \tag*{$(2)$}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $(1)$ & $(2)$ are
simultaneous equations which can be solved for $u_1$ and $d$.
  If we subtract the equation $(1)$ from the equation $(2)$ and solve
the resulting equation for $d$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} 42-24 &= (u_1 + 5d) - (u_1 + 2d) \\[6pt]
  18 &= 3d \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$

  \answer{d = 6} \hspace{4em} \\
  \end{aligned}

resulting equation for $u_1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  24 &= u_1 + 2(6) \hspace{1.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{u_1 = 12} \hspace{4.5em}

  &= \dfrac{15}{2}(2(12) + (15-1)(6)) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 810 \text{ troops}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 31
content: A ball is dropped from the top of the Eiffel Tower, $324$ metres from the ground. The ball falls a distance of $4.9$ metres during the first second, $14.7$ metres during the next second, $24.5$ metres during the third second, and so on. The distances that the ball falls each second form an arithmetic sequence. - - Find $d$, the common difference of the sequence. - Find $u_5$, the fifth term of the sequence. [2] - Find $S_6$, the sum of the first $6$ terms of the sequence. [2] - Find the time the ball will take to reach the ground. Give your answer in seconds correct to one decimal place. [3] Assuming the ball is dropped another time from a much higher height than of the Eiffel Tower, - find the distance the ball travels from the start of the $10$th second to the end of the $15$th second. [3] The Eiffel Tower in Paris, France was opened in $1889$, and $1.9$ million visitors ascended it during that first year. The number of people who visited the tower the following year ($1890$) was $2$ million. - Calculate the percentage increase in the number of visitors from $1889$ to $1890$. Give your answer correct to one decimal place. [2] - Use your answer to part (e) to estimate the number of visitors in $1900$, assuming that the number of visitors continues to increase at the same percentage rate. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have $u_1 = 4.9$ and $u_2 = 14.7$.
Hence the common difference is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &= u_2 - u_1 \hspace{1.4em} \\[6pt]
    &= 14.7 - 4.9 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 9.8\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 5$,
we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.4em} u_5 &= u_1 + (5-1)d \\[6pt]
    &= 4.9 + (5-1)(9.8) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 44.1\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.4em} S_6 &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2u_1 + (6-1)d) \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2(4.9) + (6-1)(9.8)) \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 176\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $S_n = 324$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d) &= 324 \\[3pt]
  \dfrac{n}{2}(2(4.9) + (n-1)(9.8)) &= 324 \\[6pt]
  n &\approx 8.13 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.45em} \answer{n \approx 8.1\text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 9$ and $n=15$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{15} - S_9 &= \bigg[\dfrac{15}{2}(2u_1 + (15-1)d)\bigg] - \bigg[\dfrac{9}{2}(2u_1 + (9-1)d)\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \bigg[\dfrac{15}{2}(2(4.9) + (15-1)(9.8))\bigg] - \bigg[\dfrac{9}{2}(2(4.9) + (9-1)(9.8))\bigg] \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 705.6\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the percentage increase formula
$\%\hspace{0.2em}\textbf{increase} = \dfrac{v_\mathrm{E}-v_\mathrm{S}}{v_\mathrm{S}}\times 100\hspace{0.05em}\%$
with $v_\mathrm{S} = 1.9$ and $v_\mathrm{E} = 2.0$, we obtain

  \%\hspace{0.2em}\textbf{increase} &= \dfrac{2.0-1.9}{1.9}\times100\hspace{0.05em}\% \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.3\hspace{0.05em}\%}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $v_1 = 1.9$ million
and the common ratio $r =  1.0526$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $v_n = v_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n = 12$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.8em} v_{12} &= v_1r^{12-1} \\[6pt]
  &= (1.9\text{ million})(1.0526)^{12-1} \\[7pt]

  $$

title: Question 32
content: On September 1st, an orchard commences the process of harvesting $36$ hectares of apple trees. At the end of September 4th, there were $30$ hectares remaining to be harvested, and at the end of September 8th, there were $24$ hectares remaining. Assuming that the number of hectares harvested each day is constant, the total number of hectares remaining to be harvested can be described by an arithmetic sequence. - Find the number of hectares of apple trees that are harvested each day. [3] - Determine the number of hectares remaining to be harvested at the end of September 1st. [1] - Determine the date on which the harvest will be complete. [2] In 2021 the orchard sold their apple crop for $\$220\,000$. It is expected that the selling price will then increase by $3.2\%$ annually for the next $7$ years. - Determine the amount of money the orchard will earn for their crop in 2026. Round your answer to the nearest dollar. [3] - - Find the value of $\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^8 \big(220\hspace{0.15em}000 \times 1.032^{n-1}\big)$. Round your answer to the nearest integer. - Describe, in context, what the value in part (e) (i) represents. [3] - Comment on whether it is appropriate to model this situation in terms of a geometric sequence. [1]
markScheme:
- The formula for the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_n &= u_1+(n-1)d\\[-12pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Taking $u_1$ as the number of hectares remaining to be harvested at the end of September 1st, we have $u_4=30$, and $u_8=24$. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{align}
  u_1 + 3d &= 30 \\[11pt]
  u_1 + 7d &= 24 \\[-12pt]  \nonumber
  \end{align}
  $$

  Hence subtracting (1) from (2), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  4d &= -6 \\[8pt]
  d &= -1.5 \\[-12pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, $\answer{\text{the orchard harvests $1.5$ hectares of apple trees per day.}}$
- There are 36 hectares of apple trees remaining to be harvested at the start of September 1st, and from part (a) we know that they are being harvested at 1.5 hectares per day.
  Therefore, at the end of September 1st, there are $\answer{\text{$34.5$ hectares}}\,$remaining to be harvested.
- We must find the value of $n$ such that $u_n = 0$. We have $u_1 = 34.5$ and $d = -1.5$. Therefore, using the formula for the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  34.5 + (n-1)(-1.5) &= 0\\[7pt]
  34.5 -1.5n +1.5 &= 0\\[11pt]
  36 - 1.5n &= 0 \\[11pt]
  -1.5n &= -36 \\[11pt]
  n &= \dfrac{-36}{-1.5}\\[11pt]
  n &= 24
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, $\answer{\text{the harvest will be complete at the end of September 24th.}}$
- From $2021$ until $2028$, the selling price of the apple crop can be modelled by a geometric sequence with $u_1 = 220\hspace{0.15em}000$ and $r = 1.032$. The selling price in $2026$ will be term $u_6$ in this sequence.
  Using the formula for the $n$th term in a geometric sequence, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_n &= u_1 \times r^{n-1} \\[11pt]
  u_6 &= 220\hspace{0.15em}000 \left(1.032\right)^{6-1} \\[11pt]
  &= 257526\\[-12pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In $2026$, the orchard will earn $\answer{257\,526}\,$ for their crop.
- 
  - Using the G.D.C., we obtain

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \sum_{n=1}^8 220\hspace{0.15em}000 \times 1.032^{n-1} \  \answer{\approx 1\,970\,253}\\[-12pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - $\answer{\text{The total amount earned for the apple crop from 2021 to 2028}}$

- The model is appropriate as long as:
  $\answer{\text{the selling price increases at a similar rate annually.}}$

title: Question 44
content: On Wednesday Eddy goes to a velodrome to train. He cycles the first lap of the track in $25$ seconds.   $$

title: Question 48
content: Jenni is conducting an experiment with a spring and has attached a mass so that it will oscillate up and down. She is measuring the $y$-coordinate of the centre of the mass. At the start of the experiment the mass is at rest with its centre being at the point $(0, 0)$. She gives the mass a nudge upwards in the positive $y$-direction. She makes her first measurement of $(0, 37.5)$ when the centre of the mass is at the first maximum point ($n=1$). The units of the $y$-coordinate are in millimetres. The mass then moves downwards passing the $x$-axis and reaching its first minimum point ($n=2$). Jenni makes her second measurement of the $y$-coordinate of the centre of a the mass as $(0, a)$. The mass then moves up past the $x$-axis to the next maximum point ($n=3$) and Jenni makes her third measurement of $(0, 24)$. The diagram below shows how the mass moves up and down until Jenni makes her $3$rd measurement. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5c432714-26e0-44d2-ad4c-8fbd32ef03e2/images/e1e394ce-c8ff-476f-b471-b3fad49316a7/springs.png) Jenni notices that the $y$-coordinates of the three measurements $37.5,\; a,\; 24$ form a geometric sequence. - Find $a$. [2] The spring continues to oscillate up and down with Jenni measuring the $y$-coordinate in the same way as described. The results continue to form a geometric sequence. - Find the $6$th term in the sequence. Give your answer to 3 decimal places. [2] - Show that the total distance travelled in the $y$-direction by the mass when the $6$th measurement is made is $264.408$ mm. [3]
markScheme:
- Let the common ratio of the sequence be $r$.
  As the sequence is geometric we can use the general formula for the third term...

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      u_3&=u_1r^2\\
      24&=37.5r^2\\
      r^2&=0.64\\
      r=&=\pm 0.8
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The value of $a$ is negative as the mass moves below the $x$-axis.
  Therefore $a=37.5\times(-0.8)$.
  $\answer{a=-30}$
- We can use the general formula with $n=6$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      u_6&=37.5\times(-0.8)^{6-1}\\
      &=-12.288
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The $6$th term is $\answer{u_6=-12.288}$
- Let's first review the total distance travelled when the $3$rd measurement is taken, as shown in the diagram...

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      S_3 &= 2\times u_1 + 2\times u_2 + u_3\\
      &=2(u_1 + u_2) + u_3\\
      &=2S_2 + u_3
  \end{align*}
  $$

  This means all distances before the third term must be $\times2$ as the mass must both extend to that distance and return to the $x$-axis.
  But when the measurement is taken it only extends that distance therefore we don't double the distance for that measurement.
  Using that information we can work out the total distance travelled when the $6$th measurement is taken...

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      S_6 &= 2\times u_1 + 2\times u_2 + .... 2\times u_5 + u_6\\
      &= 2(u_1 + u_2 + .... +u_5) + u_6\\
      &= 2(S_5) + u_6
  \end{align*}
  $$

  We can find the value of $S_5$ using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of a geometric sequence.
  However, realise that we must use the positive values of the $y$-coordinate as we are finding the total distance travelled. Therefore we must use $r=0.8$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      &= 2\left(\frac{37.5(1-(0.8)^5)}{1-(0.8)}\right) + 37.5\times(0.8)^{5}\\
      &=  264.408
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The total distance travelled when the $6$th measurement is taken is $\answer{264.408}$ as required.
